snippet: Offerings on a range of subjects could expose millions of overseas students to Chinese culture, if worries about academic freedom, quality and propaganda can be overcome.

byline.contributor: Mia Li and Adam Wu contributed research from Beijing.

abstract: Chinese government is turning to online education in continuing effort to promote its culture and values across globe; mainland Chinese universities now offer more than 100 online courses, covering wide range of academic subjects, on edX and other e-learning platforms; critics say handful of politically sensitive courses are nothing more than propaganda, but some scholars seem willing to give China opportunity to develop course material that offers genuine exchange of ideas.
lead_paragraph: Offerings on a range of subjects could expose millions of overseas students to Chinese culture, if worries about academic freedom, quality and propaganda can be overcome.

headline.print_headline: China Turns to Online Education, and Mao, in Its Pursuit of Soft Power
headline.main: China Turns to Online Courses, and Mao, in Pursuit of Soft Power
